docs.lead_paragraph: When Congressional Republicans returned to Washington at the start of this year, they found themselves in a tough spot. They had just been trounced at the polls, giving Democrats big majorities in both the House and the Senate. President Bush was leaving office with very low approval ratings. Barack Obama had just won the largest share of the popular vote of any presidential candidate in 20 years.
docs.abstract: How medical malpractice reform could become a bigger part of health care reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats are becoming increasingly optimistic that they will be able to pass a health care bill this year after fending off Republican attempts to fundamentally rework their legislation Wednesday. Now more than ever achieving President Obama's top legislative priority is a numbers game.

docs.lead_paragraph: The price of being an angry jerk is that nobody wants to invite you over for supper except your mother, and even she feels a little uneasy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Until now, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, the lone Republican who has expressed a willingness to support the health care legislation, has hogged the spotlight at the center of the political aisle. But with Democrats increasingly optimistic about their chances of passing a health care bill, attention will shift to centrists in their own party, whose support is likely but who are not yet fully on board.
docs.abstract: Democrats, now increasingly optimistic about their chances of passing health care legislation, will likely shift attention away from Republicans to Democratic centrists like Sen Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas and Sen Mary L Landrieu of Louisiana, whose support is likely but who are not yet fully on board; photos (M)
